Title.evidence: Effects of Remimazolam vs. Propofol on Intraoperative Neurophysiological Monitoring: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: In a prospective, double-blind design, 66 patients aged 20-70 years, with ASA physical status I-III, were randomised 1:1

Participants.evidence: 66 patients aged 20-70 years, with ASA physical status I-III, were randomised 1:1

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive either remimazolam (Group R) or propofol (Group P) along with remifentanil

Objective.evidence: compared the effects of remimazolam and propofol on intraoperative neurophysiological monitoring (IONM) during cervical spine surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in N20 latency of somatosensory-evoked potentials (SEP) measured preoperatively and 30 minutes after anesthetic induction (T1)

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment using opaque envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Patients, surgeons, and outcome assessors were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: 33 patients were randomised to each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: all were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: mean difference = 0.2 ms, 95% CI -0.3 to 0.7; p = 0.45

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups, with no severe complications reported

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by the Yonsei University Health System
